pr_title: Fix #5811 - Clicking hint field blocks key input

timeline.message:
Fix #5811 - Clicking hint field blocks key input

Using a bluetooth mouse and keyboard, clicking a `{{hint:}}` field
focused the WebView, disabling navigation via the keyboard and leaving
a permanent text bar input cursor when hovering over the WebView.

We fix this via implementing and calling new JavaScript function,
which passes control back to the Android UI

timeline.bodyText:
you have a SIGNAL_NONE which is defensive, but there's no case for it, or Timber.w for the default case. Maybe a quick Timber.w in default that says 'received unexpected signal ...' ?

  
    
      
        Suggested change
        
          
    

        
      
    
    
      
          
            
                                default:
          
          
            
                                default:
          
          
            
                                    Timber.w("Received unexpected signal '%s' from WebView. Ignoring.", url);
          
      
    
    
  

or something like that
timeline.author: mikehardy

timeline.bodyText:
My suggestion for defensive programming logging above could alternatively be here, just some notice somewhere would be nice
In addition, if you're doing short-circuit returns, you can go from else if statements to just if statements which I think require just a tiny bit less cognitive work to reason about. That's a nit thought
timeline.author: mikehardy

timeline.bodyText:
@timrae I think this is the only potential change to existing behavior - do you have an opinion? The specific review note is:

Confirm whether selecting the Text Input Field, rather than "Show Answer" on a note type with both {{hint:}} and {{type:}} is correct.
Normally, a {{type:}} field does not have this focus initially.
But, even with focus on the text input field, ENTER displays the new card.

timeline.bodyText: I don't understand how a signal that starts with answer_ease is handled, when the 4 we expect are above (and are handled in a switch when they are seen by the caller) but handled is actually not handled? who is handling it? Might be naming semantics - might be better as unhandled with a little more logging about an answer_ease value that we're not expecting?
timeline.author: mikehardy

replies.bodyText:
Yep, naming.
Currently
Unhandled: We don't know about this, it's not a signal so try intent processing.
Handled: We know about this, but have no associated action to take.
Maybe SIGNAL_HANDLED => SIGNAL_NOOP?
replies.author: david-allison-1

replies.bodyText: I guess the aim is: we want to stop execution and return true from a NOOP, and continue processing from anything unhandled.
replies.author: david-allison-1

replies.bodyText: SIGNAL_NOOP sounds good, with an associated Timber.w because it feels like it is unexpected input/state (thus more than info), but we can certainly continue processing (thus not error) ?
replies.author: mikehardy
